abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Post-Tsunami Recovery
            and Reconstruction Project for Maldives were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: this project demonstrated once again the
            importance of Governments preparing solid and reliable
            damage assessments and reconstruction plans. In this case,
            the Government's damage assessment was completed very
            quickly, effectively and efficiently with assistance from
            the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the
            United Nation (UN) system. The availability of credible
            lists of beneficiaries that was prepared very soon after the
            disaster and were broadly accepted by the community ensured
            the success and efficiency of the first round of
            distribution of cash grants to households. Despite the
            emergency character of the project, it should include some
            kind of evaluation of results. Implementation of other
            activities included in the Government's reconstruction,
            and financed by other donors, did suffer because of the
            absence of reliable beneficiary lists prepared in a timely
            fashion. Medium and small contractors may sometimes be
            better able to deliver in the aftermath of a disaster when
            large contractors are typically over-extended.
